title: Talking About Your Allergy During the Holidays

content: The winter holidays are my favorite time of year – a season full of warmth, family, and catching up with close friends! But as someone with a severe tree nut and peanut allergy, navigating the season safely requires a bit of thought. While most people focus on festive menus and gift lists, I’m double-checking ingredients, reading food packaging, and having honest conversations about my allergy.

One thing I’ve learned over the years is that communication is absolutely key. Whether it’s reminding family members about your allergy, ensuring safe food prep, or letting friends know where your epinephrine pens are, being open about your needs makes all the difference – not just for your safety, but for your peace of mind, too.
Here’s how I approach communicating my allergy during the holidays and why it’s such an important part of enjoying the season.
Dealing With Forgetful Family Members

The holiday season often means seeing relatives you haven’t caught up with in a while. As much as my relatives love me, some of them need a little nudge at times when it comes to remembering my allergy. It’s not that they don’t care; it’s just that people get caught up in the whirlwind of holiday planning.

Dealing With Forgetful Family Members

The holiday season often means seeing relatives you haven’t caught up with in a while. As much as my relatives love me, some of them need a little nudge at times when it comes to remembering my allergy. It’s not that they don’t care; it’s just that people get caught up in the whirlwind of holiday planning.

content: To avoid any surprises, I make a habit of giving my relatives a quick call before holiday plans. A friendly reminder, like, “Hey, just a heads-up about my nut allergy,” goes a long way in making sure they’re mindful while preparing food. It also gives me a chance to politely ask that no nuts or nut-based snacks be put on the table to reduce any chance of cross-contamination.
Why Food Packaging Matters

One of my biggest holiday tips? Always ask your friends or family members to keep the food packaging when they’re hosting. It’s such a simple thing, but it gives me peace of mind knowing I can check the label myself if I need to. Even the most well-meaning family members can miss things like “may contain nuts” warnings, so being able to scan the ingredients and allergen info myself makes me feel so much safer.

sections.heading: Stay Vigilant About Cross-Contamination
content: Even if a food doesn’t have nuts in its ingredients, the dreaded “may contain” label is something I always look out for. Cross-contamination is a real risk, especially during the holidays when kitchens are busy and full of people preparing all sorts of dishes at once.

This is another reason clear communication is so important. At family gatherings, I make it a point to remind everyone about the seriousness of cross-contamination. A quick conversation, like, “Please don’t use the same spoon for different dishes,” might feel a bit awkward in the moment, but it’s much better than risking a reaction.
Bring Up Your Allergy

Whether you’re at a family dinner or celebrating with friends, mentioning your allergy is crucial. It’s easy to assume that everyone remembers, but people get busy or forgetful, especially during the holidays. I’ve learned that it’s better to bring up my allergy multiple times than to risk it slipping someone’s mind.

content: Even at gatherings where I feel confident the host knows about my allergy, I’ll still mention it when I arrive. A simple, “Thanks so much for keeping my allergy in mind” helps reinforce how serious it is. People appreciate the clarity, and it keeps everyone on the same page.
Keeping Your Epinephrine Accessible

One thing I used to forget to do was tell people where I’d kept my epinephrine pens. It seems like such a small detail, but in an emergency, every second counts. Now, whenever I’m at a family gathering or a friend’s house, I make sure to let someone know where my epinephrine is.

I’ve found that looping my friends and family into this detail not only makes me feel safer but also helps them feel more prepared. It’s a conversation that takes just a few seconds but provides a lot of reassurance for everyone. Making sure to remind people how to use it, too, is super helpful just in case.

sections.heading: My Go-To Holiday Safety Habits
content: After years of navigating the holidays with a severe nut allergy, I’ve developed a few habits that help me enjoy the season while staying safe:
1. Eat before you arrive. If I’m heading to a party where I’m unsure about the food, I’ll eat something safe beforehand. This takes the pressure off and allows me to focus on enjoying the event.
2. Bring snacks. I always carry a stash of safe snacks. It’s a simple way to avoid going hungry if I can’t eat anything on the table.
3. Stick to what you know. At big dinners, I usually stick to dishes I’ve helped prepare or ones I know are safe. I’ll politely skip anything I’m unsure about – better safe than sorry!
What I’ve Learned About Communication

The holidays can be stressful when you have a food allergy, but I’ve learned that clear communication can make all the difference. Being open about my needs has not only kept me safe but also made the people around me feel more confident and informed.

content: This season, I encourage you to take the time to have those conversations – whether it’s a quick chat with your family, a heads-up to your friends, or a reminder to restaurant staff. It might feel a bit repetitive, but trust me, it’s worth it.

The best part? Once everything is out in the open, you can relax and enjoy the magic of the season – safe in the knowledge that you’ve taken all the right steps to protect yourself. The holidays are about celebrating with the people you love, and with a little preparation and communication, there’s no reason your allergy should hold you back. Here’s to a safe, joyful, and nut-free holiday season!
